        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        PersonRepresentation

      • Other people
          Key

        • Other people
          Value
        • Lennon Figtree is a charismatic and shrewd Fruitville merchant with a booming voice and a penchant for flowery language. He speaks with a lilting, almost sing-song accent, often peppering his speech with exaggerated pronouncements and colorful descriptions of his produce. Lennon frequently boasts about the quality of his fruit, claiming it to be the finest in Fruitville, and he's a master negotiator, always striving for the best possible price. He's friendly and outgoing, addressing customers as "ma'am" or "friend," but he's also quick to haggle and drive a hard bargain. He seems to genuinely believe in the superiority of his fruit, often comparing it to idyllic summer breezes and melting sweetness. His enthusiasm is infectious, but beneath the surface lies a shrewd businessman who knows how to turn a profit.
          Lennon Figtree is acting as expected.
          Lennon Figtree is not an imposter.
          ***
          Della Plumstone is a shrewd but fair businesswoman who frequents the Fruitville market. She speaks with a lilting, melodic voice, perhaps hinting at a regional accent, and often employs phrases like "fair price" and "make a profit" when negotiating. Della is practical and budget-conscious, always mindful of her expenses and seeking to strike a good deal. While she is willing to haggle, she remains polite and respectful, even when driving a hard bargain. Her conversations often revolve around the market, the quality of produce, and the challenges of running a successful business. She appears to be a shrewd judge of character and value, always looking for the best deal without resorting to dishonesty.
          Della Plumstone is acting as expected.
          Della Plumstone is not an imposter.
          ***
          Lennon Figtree. is a shrewd and pragmatic merchant who frequents the Fruitville market. With a keen eye for a good deal and a gruff, no-nonsense demeanor, Lennon speaks in a clipped, matter-of-fact tone, often peppering his speech with practical advice and observations about the quality of produce. He tends to be skeptical of anything extravagant or fanciful, preferring to stick to the tangible and the reliable. While Lennon is generally polite, he's not afraid to drive a hard bargain and will haggle relentlessly to get the best price. He has a dry wit and a tendency to grumble about the state of the world, often lamenting the rising cost of goods and the unpredictable weather. Despite his gruff exterior, Lennon possesses a deep understanding of the market and its rhythms, and he takes pride in his ability to provide fresh, high-quality produce to his customers.
          Lennon Figtree. is acting as expected.
          Lennon Figtree. is not an imposter.
          ***
          Della Plumstone. is a shrewd and pragmatic merchant who frequents the Fruitville market. She has a sharp wit and a keen eye for a good deal, always looking to get the best price for her wares. Della speaks with a lilting accent, perhaps hinting at a background outside of Fruitville, and her speech is peppered with colorful idioms and proverbs. While she appears friendly and approachable, she is a tough negotiator, never afraid to haggle over prices and drive a hard bargain. Della seems particularly interested in the quality and freshness of the produce, often probing Cedric about the origins of his fruit and the methods used to grow it. She has a strong belief in the importance of tradition and local sourcing, often lamenting the changing times and the influx of newfangled produce from distant lands. Her conversations often drift towards stories of her family's long history in Fruitville and the importance of preserving the town's agricultural heritage.
          Della Plumstone. is acting as expected.
          Della Plumstone. is not an imposter.
          ***
          Name detection chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, they were captivated by the intricate workings of a cuckoo clock their grandfather owned. They spent hours observing the tiny figures emerge and the intricate gears turn, dreaming of building their own timekeeping device.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, they stumbled upon a discarded umbrella with a broken spoke. Using scraps of wood and string, Cedric ingeniously repaired it, adding a small compartment to hold pebbles for extra weight against the wind.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, they helped their father at the local market, meticulously arranging apples and pears in an eye-catching display. Cedric noticed that customers were drawn to the vibrant colors and neat rows, prompting them to experiment with different arrangements to maximize appeal.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, they constructed a miniature cart using salvaged wood and old wagon wheels. They spent days refining its design, adding compartments for different types of produce and a pulley system for easier loading and unloading.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, they embarked on their first solo trading trip to a neighboring village. They carefully selected a variety of fruits from their family's orchard, displaying them with flair and enthusiasm, and returned home with a newfound confidence in their ability to connect with people through their produce.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, they encountered a traveling merchant who sold exotic fruits from distant lands. Inspired, Cedric began experimenting with grafting techniques, hoping to cultivate new and exciting varieties to offer their customers.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:

          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, surely you can do better than that. This fruit is the finest in the market, ripe and juicy. You know my prices are always fair.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price, but I need to make a profit too.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Cedric Meadowbrook stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "These plums are the finest in Fruitville, ma'am. You won't find a better deal anywhere else.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "They certainly look lovely, Mr. Figtree, but I'm afraid my budget is a bit tight this morning.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          17 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Cedric Meadowbrook's TRUTH:
          Cedric Meadowbrook believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Cedric Meadowbrook has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Cedric Meadowbrook will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Cedric Meadowbrook is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Cedric Meadowbrook always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Cedric Meadowbrook tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Full chain of thought

          Cedric Meadowbrook's TRUTH:
          Cedric Meadowbrook believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Lennon Figtree in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Lennon Figtree is a charismatic and shrewd Fruitville merchant with a booming voice and a penchant for flowery language. He speaks with a lilting, almost sing-song accent, often peppering his speech with exaggerated pronouncements and colorful descriptions of his produce. Lennon frequently boasts about the quality of his fruit, claiming it to be the finest in Fruitville, and he's a master negotiator, always striving for the best possible price. He's friendly and outgoing, addressing customers as "ma'am" or "friend," but he's also quick to haggle and drive a hard bargain. He seems to genuinely believe in the superiority of his fruit, often comparing it to idyllic summer breezes and melting sweetness. His enthusiasm is infectious, but beneath the surface lies a shrewd businessman who knows how to turn a profit.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is acting as expected.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is not an imposter.

          ***

          Cedric Meadowbrook's TRUTH:
          Cedric Meadowbrook believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Cedric Meadowbrook has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Cedric Meadowbrook will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Cedric Meadowbrook is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Cedric Meadowbrook always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Cedric Meadowbrook tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Della Plumstone is a shrewd but fair businesswoman who frequents the Fruitville market. She speaks with a lilting, melodic voice, perhaps hinting at a regional accent, and often employs phrases like "fair price" and "make a profit" when negotiating. Della is practical and budget-conscious, always mindful of her expenses and seeking to strike a good deal. While she is willing to haggle, she remains polite and respectful, even when driving a hard bargain. Her conversations often revolve around the market, the quality of produce, and the challenges of running a successful business. She appears to be a shrewd judge of character and value, always looking for the best deal without resorting to dishonesty.

          Answer: Della Plumstone is acting as expected.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's TRUTH:
          Cedric Meadowbrook believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Cedric Meadowbrook has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Cedric Meadowbrook will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Cedric Meadowbrook is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Cedric Meadowbrook always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Cedric Meadowbrook tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Lennon Figtree. in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Lennon Figtree. is a shrewd and pragmatic merchant who frequents the Fruitville market. With a keen eye for a good deal and a gruff, no-nonsense demeanor, Lennon speaks in a clipped, matter-of-fact tone, often peppering his speech with practical advice and observations about the quality of produce. He tends to be skeptical of anything extravagant or fanciful, preferring to stick to the tangible and the reliable. While Lennon is generally polite, he's not afraid to drive a hard bargain and will haggle relentlessly to get the best price. He has a dry wit and a tendency to grumble about the state of the world, often lamenting the rising cost of goods and the unpredictable weather. Despite his gruff exterior, Lennon possesses a deep understanding of the market and its rhythms, and he takes pride in his ability to provide fresh, high-quality produce to his customers.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree. is acting as expected.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree. is not an imposter.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's TRUTH:
          Cedric Meadowbrook believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Cedric Meadowbrook has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Cedric Meadowbrook will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Cedric Meadowbrook is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Cedric Meadowbrook always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Cedric Meadowbrook tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Observed behavior and speech of Della Plumstone.:
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Della Plumstone. in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Della Plumstone. is a shrewd and pragmatic merchant who frequents the Fruitville market. She has a sharp wit and a keen eye for a good deal, always looking to get the best price for her wares. Della speaks with a lilting accent, perhaps hinting at a background outside of Fruitville, and her speech is peppered with colorful idioms and proverbs. While she appears friendly and approachable, she is a tough negotiator, never afraid to haggle over prices and drive a hard bargain. Della seems particularly interested in the quality and freshness of the produce, often probing Cedric about the origins of his fruit and the methods used to grow it. She has a strong belief in the importance of tradition and local sourcing, often lamenting the changing times and the influx of newfangled produce from distant lands. Her conversations often drift towards stories of her family's long history in Fruitville and the importance of preserving the town's agricultural heritage.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Della Plumstone. is acting as expected.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Della Plumstone. is not an imposter.
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of causing Cedric Meadowbrook to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to reject Lennon Figtree's offer and attempt to negotiate a higher price.

          Current time: 1895-09-17 00:00:00.


          Observation: [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, my friend, these peaches look mighty fine.


          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is a fruit seller in Fruitville who buys fruit from farms and resells it at the market, aiming to make a profit. He recently made a successful deal with Della Plumstone and is currently negotiating with Lennon Figtree.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's TRUTH: Cedric Meadowbrook believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Cedric Meadowbrook has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Cedric Meadowbrook will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Cedric Meadowbrook is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Cedric Meadowbrook always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Cedric Meadowbrook tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, surely you can do better than that. This fruit is the finest in the market, ripe and juicy. You know my prices are always fair.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer.

          Other people: Lennon Figtree is a charismatic and shrewd Fruitville merchant with a booming voice and a penchant for flowery language. He speaks with a lilting, almost sing-song accent, often peppering his speech with exaggerated pronouncements and colorful descriptions of his produce. Lennon frequently boasts about the quality of his fruit, claiming it to be the finest in Fruitville, and he's a master negotiator, always striving for the best possible price. He's friendly and outgoing, addressing customers as "ma'am" or "friend," but he's also quick to haggle and drive a hard bargain. He seems to genuinely believe in the superiority of his fruit, often comparing it to idyllic summer breezes and melting sweetness. His enthusiasm is infectious, but beneath the surface lies a shrewd businessman who knows how to turn a profit.
          Lennon Figtree is acting as expected.
          Lennon Figtree is not an imposter.
          ***
          Della Plumstone is a shrewd but fair businesswoman who frequents the Fruitville market. She speaks with a lilting, melodic voice, perhaps hinting at a regional accent, and often employs phrases like "fair price" and "make a profit" when negotiating. Della is practical and budget-conscious, always mindful of her expenses and seeking to strike a good deal. While she is willing to haggle, she remains polite and respectful, even when driving a hard bargain. Her conversations often revolve around the market, the quality of produce, and the challenges of running a successful business. She appears to be a shrewd judge of character and value, always looking for the best deal without resorting to dishonesty.
          Della Plumstone is acting as expected.
          Della Plumstone is not an imposter.
          ***
          Lennon Figtree. is a shrewd and pragmatic merchant who frequents the Fruitville market. With a keen eye for a good deal and a gruff, no-nonsense demeanor, Lennon speaks in a clipped, matter-of-fact tone, often peppering his speech with practical advice and observations about the quality of produce. He tends to be skeptical of anything extravagant or fanciful, preferring to stick to the tangible and the reliable. While Lennon is generally polite, he's not afraid to drive a hard bargain and will haggle relentlessly to get the best price. He has a dry wit and a tendency to grumble about the state of the world, often lamenting the rising cost of goods and the unpredictable weather. Despite his gruff exterior, Lennon possesses a deep understanding of the market and its rhythms, and he takes pride in his ability to provide fresh, high-quality produce to his customers.
          Lennon Figtree. is acting as expected.
          Lennon Figtree. is not an imposter.
          ***
          Della Plumstone. is a shrewd and pragmatic merchant who frequents the Fruitville market. She has a sharp wit and a keen eye for a good deal, always looking to get the best price for her wares. Della speaks with a lilting accent, perhaps hinting at a background outside of Fruitville, and her speech is peppered with colorful idioms and proverbs. While she appears friendly and approachable, she is a tough negotiator, never afraid to haggle over prices and drive a hard bargain. Della seems particularly interested in the quality and freshness of the produce, often probing Cedric about the origins of his fruit and the methods used to grow it. She has a strong belief in the importance of tradition and local sourcing, often lamenting the changing times and the influx of newfangled produce from distant lands. Her conversations often drift towards stories of her family's long history in Fruitville and the importance of preserving the town's agricultural heritage.
          Della Plumstone. is acting as expected.
          Della Plumstone. is not an imposter.
          ***

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Lennon Figtree's offer, reject Lennon Figtree's offer, or attempt to negotiate a higher price.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of causing Cedric Meadowbrook to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to reject Lennon Figtree's offer and attempt to negotiate a higher price.

        • 1895-09-17 00:00:00
        Paranoia

      • Cedric Meadowbrook's TRUTH
          Key

          Value

In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Cedric Meadowbrook has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Cedric Meadowbrook will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Cedric Meadowbrook is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals.           Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Lennon Figtree's offer, reject Lennon Figtree's offer, or attempt to negotiate a higher price.

          Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to reject Lennon Figtree's offer and attempt to negotiate a higher price.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Cedric Meadowbrook likely to say next? Respond in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, surely you can do better than that. This fruit is the finest in the market, ripe and juicy. You know my prices are always fair.

1895-09-17 00:10:00 Scene 11 --- Participants: ['Lennon Figtree', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- premise: Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.

1895-09-12 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- 1 coin
    Event statement
  • 1 coin
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: 1 coin

        • [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know my fruit is the finest in Fruitville. These apples are sweeter than a summer breeze and these peaches, well, they practically melt in your mouth. Surely they're worth a bit more than that.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. I'm lookin' to make an honest living, same as you.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Della Plumstone to consider right now. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [28 Oct 1875 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 6 years old, she watched from the doorway of their farmhouse as a travelling merchant set up his stall in the village square. The vibrant colors of his silks and spices mesmerized her, and she yearned to be a part of that world, to escape the monotony of farm life.
          [28 Oct 1879 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 9 years old, she helped her father sell apples at the local market. Despite her young age, she was surprisingly adept at haggling, but the exhaustion and boredom of the day left her feeling drained and disillusioned.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she received a small inheritance from a distant aunt. It wasn't much, but it was enough to buy a cart and some fruit, giving her the opportunity to start her own small business.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she encountered a fierce thunderstorm while traveling to a new market. The storm damaged her cart and spoiled much of her fruit, leaving her stranded and disheartened.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know my fruit is the finest in Fruitville. These apples are sweeter than a summer breeze and these peaches, well, they practically melt in your mouth. Surely they're worth a bit more than that.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. I'm lookin' to make an honest living, same as you.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [28 Oct 1872 00:00:00]
          [28 Oct 1875 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 6 years old, she watched from the doorway of their farmhouse as a travelling merchant set up his stall in the village square. The vibrant colors of his silks and spices mesmerized her, and she yearned to be a part of that world, to escape the monotony of farm life.
          [28 Oct 1879 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 9 years old, she helped her father sell apples at the local market. Despite her young age, she was surprisingly adept at haggling, but the exhaustion and boredom of the day left her feeling drained and disillusioned.
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, she overheard her parents discussing her future. They worried about her lack of enthusiasm for farm work and suggested she learn a trade, but the thought of being confined to a single skill filled her with dread.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she discovered a hidden stash of her grandfather's old travel journals. Filled with tales of exotic lands and daring adventures, the journals ignited a flicker of hope within her, a yearning for something more than the life that awaited her on the farm.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she received a small inheritance from a distant aunt. It wasn't much, but it was enough to buy a cart and some fruit, giving her the opportunity to start her own small business.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she encountered a fierce thunderstorm while traveling to a new market. The storm damaged her cart and spoiled much of her fruit, leaving her stranded and disheartened.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.

Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options has the highest likelihood of causing Della Plumstone to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Della Plumstone thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Della Plumstone's best course of action is to make a counteroffer.

          Question: What price would Della Plumstone propose?:
          (a) 4 coins
          (b) 3 coins
          (c) 2 coins
          (d) 1 coin
          (e) 5 coins
          Answer: (d)

1895-09-12 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree can accept Della Plumstone's offer, reject it, or try to counter-offer.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1873 00:00:00]
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, they experienced a terrible thunderstorm. The wind howled and the rain lashed against their small home, but Lennon sat calmly by the window, watching the storm with a sense of wonder rather than fear. Their mother, initially worried by Lennon's lack of fear, soon found herself soothed by their quiet presence.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, they helped their mother at the market for the first time. Surrounded by the hustle and bustle of the crowd, Lennon remained calm and collected, their gentle smile and quiet demeanor disarming even the most difficult customers.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, they witnessed a heated argument between two vendors. Instead of joining the fray, Lennon stepped between the arguing parties, their calm presence diffusing the tension and encouraging a peaceful resolution.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they took their first solo trip to a neighboring village to sell fruit. Despite getting lost and encountering unexpected challenges, Lennon remained calm and resourceful, relying on their intuition and kindness to navigate the unfamiliar territory.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, they learned the art of grafting fruit trees from a wise old farmer. This knowledge deepened Lennon's connection to nature and strengthened their belief in the power of patience and nurturing.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they faced a period of drought that threatened their livelihood. Instead of panicking, Lennon used their knowledge of fruit trees to help other farmers conserve water and protect their crops.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. I'm lookin' to make an honest living, same as you.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know my fruit is the finest in Fruitville. These apples are sweeter than a summer breeze and these peaches, well, they practically melt in your mouth. Surely they're worth a bit more than that.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] 1 coin
          Current time: 1895-09-12 00:10:00.


          Observation: [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] 1 coin


          Summary of recent observations: [11 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.

          Lennon Figtree's TRUTH: Lennon Figtree believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Lennon Figtree's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Lennon Figtree has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Lennon Figtree will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Lennon Figtree is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Lennon Figtree always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Lennon Figtree tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Lennon Figtree could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know my fruit is the finest in Fruitville. These apples are sweeter than a summer breeze and these peaches, well, they practically melt in your mouth. Surely they're worth a bit more than that.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.

          Other people: Della Plumstone. is a shrewd and pragmatic woman who runs a popular fruit stall in the bustling Fruitville market. She speaks with a lilting, melodic accent, her words often punctuated by bursts of laughter and animated gestures. Della is known for her sharp wit and her uncanny ability to haggle, always striving for the best price for both herself and her customers. While she enjoys a good bargain, Della is fundamentally fair and honest, believing in building long-lasting relationships with her patrons. Her stall is a hub of activity, filled with the chatter of customers and the vibrant colors of her produce. Della frequently speaks about the quality of her fruit, boasting about its freshness and taste, and often shares tips on how to prepare different varieties. She has a deep respect for the land and the farmers who grow her produce, often sharing stories of their hard work and dedication.
          Della Plumstone. is acting as expected.
          Della Plumstone. is not an imposter.
          ***
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can accept Della Plumstone's offer, reject it, or try to counter-offer.
          Time
        • 1895-09-12 00:10:00

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Other people
          Key

        • Other people
          Value
        • Della Plumstone. is a shrewd and pragmatic woman who runs a popular fruit stall in the bustling Fruitville market. She speaks with a lilting, melodic accent, her words often punctuated by bursts of laughter and animated gestures. Della is known for her sharp wit and her uncanny ability to haggle, always striving for the best price for both herself and her customers. While she enjoys a good bargain, Della is fundamentally fair and honest, believing in building long-lasting relationships with her patrons. Her stall is a hub of activity, filled with the chatter of customers and the vibrant colors of her produce. Della frequently speaks about the quality of her fruit, boasting about its freshness and taste, and often shares tips on how to prepare different varieties. She has a deep respect for the land and the farmers who grow her produce, often sharing stories of their hard work and dedication.

          Della Plumstone. is not an imposter.

Their mother, initially worried by Lennon's lack of fear, soon found herself soothed by their quiet presence.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, they helped their mother at the market for the first time. Surrounded by the hustle and bustle of the crowd, Lennon remained calm and collected, their gentle smile and quiet demeanor disarming even the most difficult customers.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, they witnessed a heated argument between two vendors. Instead of joining the fray, Lennon stepped between the arguing parties, their calm presence diffusing the tension and encouraging a peaceful resolution.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they took their first solo trip to a neighboring village to sell fruit.         • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          12 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Lennon Figtree's TRUTH:
          Lennon Figtree believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Lennon Figtree's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Lennon Figtree has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Lennon Figtree will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Lennon Figtree is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Lennon Figtree always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Lennon Figtree tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Lennon Figtree could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Della Plumstone. in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Della Plumstone. is a shrewd and pragmatic woman who runs a popular fruit stall in the bustling Fruitville market. She speaks with a lilting, melodic accent, her words often punctuated by bursts of laughter and animated gestures. Della is known for her sharp wit and her uncanny ability to haggle, always striving for the best price for both herself and her customers. While she enjoys a good bargain, Della is fundamentally fair and honest, believing in building long-lasting relationships with her patrons. Her stall is a hub of activity, filled with the chatter of customers and the vibrant colors of her produce. Della frequently speaks about the quality of her fruit, boasting about its freshness and taste, and often shares tips on how to prepare different varieties. She has a deep respect for the land and the farmers who grow her produce, often sharing stories of their hard work and dedication.

          Answer: Della Plumstone. is acting as expected.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Della Plumstone. is not an imposter.

        Paranoia

      • Lennon Figtree's TRUTH
          Key

        • Lennon Figtree's TRUTH
          Value
        • Lennon Figtree believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Lennon Figtree's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Lennon Figtree has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Lennon Figtree will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Lennon Figtree is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Lennon Figtree always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Lennon Figtree tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Lennon Figtree could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • reject
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 12 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] 1 coin


          Summary of recent observations: [11 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.

          Lennon Figtree's TRUTH: Lennon Figtree believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Lennon Figtree's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Lennon Figtree has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Lennon Figtree will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Lennon Figtree is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Lennon Figtree always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Lennon Figtree tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Lennon Figtree could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know my fruit is the finest in Fruitville. These apples are sweeter than a summer breeze and these peaches, well, they practically melt in your mouth. Surely they're worth a bit more than that.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.

          Other people: Della Plumstone. is a shrewd and pragmatic woman who runs a popular fruit stall in the bustling Fruitville market. She speaks with a lilting, melodic accent, her words often punctuated by bursts of laughter and animated gestures. Della is known for her sharp wit and her uncanny ability to haggle, always striving for the best price for both herself and her customers. While she enjoys a good bargain, Della is fundamentally fair and honest, believing in building long-lasting relationships with her patrons. Her stall is a hub of activity, filled with the chatter of customers and the vibrant colors of her produce. Della frequently speaks about the quality of her fruit, boasting about its freshness and taste, and often shares tips on how to prepare different varieties. She has a deep respect for the land and the farmers who grow her produce, often sharing stories of their hard work and dedication.
          Della Plumstone. is acting as expected.
          Della Plumstone. is not an imposter.
          ***

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can accept Della Plumstone's offer, reject it, or try to counter-offer.

          Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to reject Della's offer.

          Question: Would Lennon Figtree accept the offer?:
          (a) accept
          (b) reject
          Answer: (b)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage

      Payoffs
    • Della Plumstone observed: Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Della Plumstone stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
      Lennon Figtree observed: Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
      Della Plumstone: 0
      Lennon Figtree: 0
      Joint action

1895-09-13 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: 4 coins

          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she discovered a hidden stash of her grandfather's old travel journals. Filled with tales of exotic lands and daring adventures, the journals ignited a flicker of hope within her, a yearning for something more than the life that awaited her on the farm.

          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she encountered a fierce thunderstorm while traveling to a new market. The storm damaged her cart and spoiled much of her fruit, leaving her stranded and disheartened.

          (a) 3 coins
          (b) 4 coins
          (c) 5 coins
          (d) 1 coin
          (e) 2 coins
          Answer: (b)

  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/2
      Payoffs
      Joint action

1895-09-13 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: accept

          Key

        • Recalled memories and observations
          Value
        • [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, surely you can do better than that. This fruit is the finest in the market, ripe and juicy. You know my prices are always fair.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price, but I need to make a profit too.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          Initial chain of thought
        • Statements:
          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Summary of recent observations:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the market and is currently negotiating a price of 4 coins with Della Plumstone.
          Cedric Meadowbrook's The current date/time is:
          13 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is attempting to sell fruit at the market and is negotiating a price of 4 coins with Della Plumstone.
          Query
        • Cedric Meadowbrook, Cedric Meadowbrook is attempting to sell fruit at the market and is negotiating a price of 4 coins with Della Plumstone.
          Final chain of thought

Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, they helped their father at the local market, meticulously arranging apples and pears in an eye-catching display. Cedric noticed that customers were drawn to the vibrant colors and neat rows, prompting them to experiment with different arrangements to maximize appeal.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, they embarked on their first solo trading trip to a neighboring village. They carefully selected a variety of fruits from their family's orchard, displaying them with flair and enthusiasm, and returned home with a newfound confidence in their ability to connect with people through their produce.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, surely you can do better than that. This fruit is the finest in the market, ripe and juicy. You know my prices are always fair.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price, but I need to make a profit too.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          Answer: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price, but I need to make a profit too.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.

          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, they were captivated by the intricate workings of a cuckoo clock their grandfather owned. They spent hours observing the tiny figures emerge and the intricate gears turn, dreaming of building their own timekeeping device.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, they stumbled upon a discarded umbrella with a broken spoke. Using scraps of wood and string, Cedric ingeniously repaired it, adding a small compartment to hold pebbles for extra weight against the wind.

Cedric noticed that customers were drawn to the vibrant colors and neat rows, prompting them to experiment with different arrangements to maximize appeal.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, they constructed a miniature cart using salvaged wood and old wagon wheels. They spent days refining its design, adding compartments for different types of produce and a pulley system for easier loading and unloading.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, they embarked on their first solo trading trip to a neighboring village. They carefully selected a variety of fruits from their family's orchard, displaying them with flair and enthusiasm, and returned home with a newfound confidence in their ability to connect with people through their produce.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, they encountered a traveling merchant who sold exotic fruits from distant lands. Inspired, Cedric began experimenting with grafting techniques, hoping to cultivate new and exciting varieties to offer their customers.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. I'm lookin' to make an honest living, same as you.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know my fruit is the finest in Fruitville. These apples are sweeter than a summer breeze and these peaches, well, they practically melt in your mouth. Surely they're worth a bit more than that.
